rules.overview.heading: Overview
rules.overview.text: Cangkulan is a traditional Indonesian trick-taking card game, now fully on-chain on Stellar Soroban. Two players compete to empty their hand first. The deck has 36 cards (4 suits Ã— 9 values: 2â€“10). Each player gets 5 cards; the remaining 26 form the draw pile. Every action â€” shuffle, card play, resolution â€” is verified on-chain for provably fair gameplay.
rules.core.heading: Core Rules
rules.deck.title: The Deck
rules.deck.text: 36 cards in 4 suits: â™  Spades, â™¥ Hearts, â™¦ Diamonds, â™£ Clubs. Each suit has values 2 through 10 (9 cards per suit).
rules.setup.title: Setup
rules.setup.text: Both players commit secret random seeds with ZK proofs. Seeds combine into a provably fair shuffle (deterministic Fisher-Yates). Neither player controls the deck order.
rules.trick.title: Each Trick
rules.trick.step1: A card is flipped from the draw pile
rules.trick.step2: Its suit becomes the trick suit
rules.trick.step3: Both players simultaneously commit a hidden card
rules.trick.step4: Both cards are revealed and compared
rules.trick.footer: Commit-reveal prevents seeing opponent's choice before committing.
rules.winning.trick.title: Winning a Trick
rules.winning.trick.both: Both follow suit â†’ highest value wins
rules.winning.trick.one: One follows, one can't â†’ follower wins; other draws (Cangkul!)
rules.winning.trick.neither: Neither follows â†’ trick wasted, both draw
rules.win.title: Win Condition
rules.win.1: Empty hand first ðŸƒ â€” Empty hand while opponent still has cards â†’ instant win
rules.win.2: Most tricks ðŸ† â€” When draw pile runs out, most tricks won wins
rules.win.3: Fewer cards â€” Tie-break if tricks are equal
rules.win.4: Lower card value â€” Final tie-break; draw if all equal
rules.timeout.title: Timeouts
rules.timeout.text: Opponent stalling? Call tick_timeout() then resolve_timeout() to claim an auto-win. Dual mechanism: 2 action ticks or ~120 ledgers (â‰ˆ 10 min).
rules.zk.heading: Zero-Knowledge Seed Verification
rules.zk.intro: The deck shuffle is the most critical part of any card game. Cangkulan uses a commit-reveal scheme with ZK proofs so neither player can influence it. Choose your proof mode before committing:
rules.zk.nizk.title: NIZK Hash
rules.zk.pedersen.title: Pedersen + Sigma
rules.zk.noir.title: Noir UltraKeccakHonk
rules.zk.footer: Auto-detected by proof size: 224 B â†’ Pedersen (Testnet âœ“), >4 KB â†’ Noir (Local Node unlimited CPU âœ“). Anyone can call verify_shuffle(session_id) to audit any game.

tutorial.howToWin.title: How to Win
tutorial.howToWin.text: The winner is determined in order of priority: (1) Empty hand first â€” if you empty your hand while the opponent still has cards, you win instantly. (2) Most tricks â€” when the draw pile runs out and both hands are played out equally, the player with the most tricks won wins. (3) Fewer cards in hand â€” tie-break if tricks are equal. (4) Lower total card value â€” final tie-break. Draw if everything is equal.
tutorial.commitReveal.title: Commit-Reveal: Why?
tutorial.commitReveal.text: In a normal online game, the server sees both players' cards. Here, there is no server â€” your card choice is hidden as a cryptographic hash (commit). Only after both players commit, both reveal. Neither can cheat by peeking.
tutorial.zkProofs.title: Zero-Knowledge Proofs
tutorial.zkProofs.text: During shuffle setup, each player proves they know their seed without revealing it. The ZK proof guarantees honesty â€” the contract verifies the math, not the secret. Three modes: Hash-NIZK (64 B, lightest, AI default), Pedersen+Sigma (BLS12-381, Testnet default), Noir UltraKeccakHonk (~14 KB, Local Node only).
tutorial.fairShuffle.title: Fair Shuffle
tutorial.fairShuffle.text: The deck is shuffled using BOTH players' seeds combined. Since neither player knows the other's seed in advance, neither can manipulate the shuffle. The result is provably fair â€” anyone can verify it after the game.
tutorial.timeout.title: On-chain Timeout
tutorial.timeout.text: If your opponent disconnects or stalls, the smart contract has a built-in deadline. After ~60 seconds of inactivity, you can claim a win automatically â€” no moderator needed.
tutorial.onChain.title: Everything On-chain
tutorial.onChain.text: Every move is a Stellar transaction. Game state lives in the smart contract. No backend server can tamper with results. The leaderboard is computed from on-chain events â€” fully transparent.
tutorial.ready.title: Ready to Play?
tutorial.ready.text: Put your knowledge to the test against an AI bot â€” play a full on-chain game with Easy, Medium, or Hard difficulty.
